METS:xmlData.dcterms:title: Evropski vplivi na slovensko družbo. Primer mesta Trst
METS:xmlData.dcterms:alternative: European Influences on Slovene Society. A Case Study of the City of Trieste
METS:xmlData.dcterms:creator: Pahor, Milan
METS:xmlData.dcterms:abstract: Avtor obravnava pomen mesta Trst v slovenski zgodovini, preko katerega so v slovenski prostor prihajali mnogi novi izzivi iz Evrope. Na začetek postavi bivanje reformatorja Primoža Trubarja v Trstu in izid slovensko-italijanskega slovarja leta 1607 v Devinu. Obravnavo nadaljuje s pomladjo narodov v letu 1848, dograditvijo Narodnega doma v letu 1904, kije pomenil afirmacijo slovenstva v mestu, požiga le-tega in etničnega čiščenja v času fašizma, prvega antifašizma v Evropi, preko druge svetovne vojne in zmage slovenskega osvobodilnega boja kot dela zavezniške koalicije. Povojni politični pluralizem v Italiji in Trstu je vplival na takratno slovensko državno socialistično ureditev in prav preko Trsta so pronicali evropski vplivi in modeli zahodne družbene ureditve.

Examined is the importance of thè city of Trieste and the role it had played in Slovene history as transmitter of novel ideas and concepts from other parts of Europe. It started with reformer Primož Trubar, who for some time had stayed in Trieste, and the 1607 publication of thè Slovene-Italian dictionary in Duino. It continued with the 1848 revolutionary Spring of Nations; completion of the building of the National home in Trieste in 1904, which denoted an important affirmation of Slovenes in this city; its arson and ethnic cleansing during thè fascist regime; the appearance of the first European anti-fascist résistance; and the Second World War and the victory of thè Slovene libération movement as a part of the Allied Coalition. The post-war politicai pluralism in Italy, and also in Trieste, likewise exerted considérable influence upon the socialist regime in Slovenia; it was namely through Trieste that European influences and models of Western législation seeped across the border and into Slovenia.
